subtitle: HIV: how do I protect him?
title: HIV-AIDS: how do I protect him?
content:
Created by BabyCenter

If you are living with HIV-AIDS there is a lot you can do to protect your baby from getting HIV-AIDS.

During pregnancy, take your antiretrovirals (ARVs) and go to the clinic for regular check-ups.

When labour starts, go straight to the health facility. You need extra care in early labour to prevent the HIV-AIDS virus being passed to your baby. 

When your baby is here, it is important that you both take your ARVs. 

Your baby needs a daily dose of ARV syrup for 4 to 6 weeks after the birth, to protect him from HIV-AIDS. Your baby will need a blood test at the clinic at around 6 weeks to check if the HIV-AIDS virus has passed to him.

Make sure you touch your baby with clean hands. Cover all cuts and wounds with a bandage until they heal. 

HIV-AIDS is a long-term illness. With the right medicines, you can manage and control it.
